In Sidney Lumet's 12 Angry Men, a teenage boy is accused of murdering his father and on trial for the death sentence. His fate is left to a jury of twelve men of different backgrounds and motivations. Some find this national duty burdensome, some are proud of America for being a democracy, others like Davis take their role seriously as a life is at stake. The film shows how Davis painstakingly convinces the rest of the jury that there is reasonable doubt of the accused's guilt, despite facing strong resistance from the start. Thanks to Davis, the outcome ultimately favours the accused. The most gripping part of this movie is how the negotiation process plays out, and the tables turn - all whilst a person's life hangs in the balance.

The amazing feature of this movie was that it was carried out in a single set. The movie hardly shows a scene outside of the discussion room. Yet, the dialogue between the jurors kept me in suspense throughout! The plot is simple and the script is ingenious. The character development as really plays well to the plot. This movie highlights the multifaceted complexities within a jury system and society in general. Excellent and a definite must watch!

12 Angry Men is a film that illustrates the diversity present in the society that we live in, and how the discordant ideas of people can fuel but also complicate negotiations. Although somewhat unrealistic due to extremely polar depictions of human behaviour, the movie manages to capture the characteristics of people from different walks of life, manifested in each of the twelve jurors.Some analysis with minor spoilers!!
Juror #8, the "hero" of the movie, displays objectivity and empathy, and gradually earns respect as a leader. From the outset, although ridiculed and singled out by the other eleven, he was unmoving with his open-minded stance that the boy deserved a fair chance to be acquitted. As Fisher and Ury put it in the book "Getting To Yes", "Never yield to pressure, only to principle". He believed in using "fair standards", thus he attempted to rally the others to be empathetic. If they were in the boy's situation, wouldn't they want their jury to be impartial and take their jobs seriously, especially since a life is at stake? Using the "principle of reciprocity", he brought awareness to the consequences of the decision, subtly appealing to those more rational. Being grounded and respected helps a lot when negotiating, because humans naturally tend to trust and follow someone they respect. In negotiations, the only certainty is that we will encounter a vast array of backgrounds, personalities, and ideologies. Despite being the cardinal concern over the course of the film, the reality of guilt or innocence turns out unimportant. Exemplifying how a diverse group of people can reach a unanimous, amicable decision, 12 Angry Men serves as a reminder that a wide range of perspectives, as well as positive negotiation skills, are crucial in any negotiation.

In 12 Angry Men, 12 jurors deliberate a murder case. The defendant is an 18 year old boy from the slums and all 12 of the jurors have to unanimously agree, on the basis of reasonable doubt, whether or not the boy should be found guilty and henceforth receive a mandatory death sentence.Through depicting skilful negotiation by the protagonist, the film effectively addresses important societal issues such as prejudice, stereotypes and discrimination. Interestingly, though it was produced over half a century ago, it still remains extremely relevant today. This is unfortunate, as it shows how little society has progressed. However, the plot's progress gives us a silver lining and shows us that ultimately, objectivity transcends prejudice and emotions.
I do not understand how you can film so well in 1957. This is one of the few films of the time that I liked. Therefore, the assessment corresponds to 8/10

Review title: Negotiation techniques in an amazing film
Review_body: "However you decide, your verdict must be unanimous... you are faced with a great responsibility". With those words, a jury is sent to deliberate the fate of a defendant. 12 Angry Men portrays the jury's process of coming to that crucial consensus. While eleven jurors deem the defendant guilty, Juror 8 (8) attempts to change their minds through a series of negotiations and reasoning. He utilises logic and sticks to his principles and belief in the face of majority opposition. Coupled with the jury members' receptiveness, it allows them to reach a unanimous decision that also reminds us about the need for empathy in decision-making. 8 controls his emotions and does not let it cloud his judgement, rather depending on objectivity to make his case as well as interact with the other jurors. In this aspect, we see the contrast between jurors. 8 is calm, listening respectfully and reflecting back what he hears. Meanwhile, Juror 10 (10) and 3 give in to their emotions, going on angry tirades and allowing prejudices to cloud their judgement. For example, 3 wrongly accuses Juror 5 (5) of changing his vote on the assumption that he is biased because of his upbringing in the slum. He also mocks Juror 9 (9), asking him to sell his sayings to newspapers. Similarly, 10 allows his prejudice to affect his emotions, ranting that "We're facing a danger here... they are wild animals... they want to destroy us", implying that he votes guilty because he views "these people" as dangerous animals, not because of the evidence. This failure to correct for skewed vision causes 10 and 3 to interpret information in a self-serving way. Their prejudice colours their interpretation of information and how they treat others, creating tension toward them that ultimately works against them. The antagonism they create in the room undermines their credibility as the film progresses. By sticking to his principles, 8 manages to keep his objectiveness and impartiality, remaining consistent even in the face of immense pressure. As the only juror who votes 'not guilty', 8 acts as the sole dissentor, the minority that social scientists identify as one who influences behaviours through consistency. By consistently believing that it is the jury's duty to preserve the law, 8 stands his ground and does not accept a bottom line where the issue would be pushed to a new jury for a retrial. Instead, he remains firm and sets out objective criteria, using logic to influence and swing the jury to his side. Hence, we see that our principles must be consistent in order to logically influence others as the minority.The outcomes of negotiations often affect the lives of people. As 8 says, "We're talking about somebody's life here". Empathy goes a long way in making such decisions. If the jury voted guilty, 10 and 3 might have 'won' in their respective positions, but a life would have been lost. Hence, although we are tasked to separate people from the problem, we must also consider the people in the solutions. By being empathetic, we can understand why certain people take up particular positions, and also prevent ourselves from making similar mistakes. Thus, although negotiation is often mistaken as a win-loss scenario, it is not the case. Through positive and collaborative negotiation, we can reach a consensus that benefits everyone.

12 Angry Men tells the tale of twelve jurors trying to come to a consensus on the verdict for a case of homicide, in which they will have to decide if a boy is innocent or guilty of killing his father on the basis of reasonable doubt. Through the heated exchanges among the jurors and the intriguing build up of the case as the story unfolds, we discover more about the distinctive personalities and backgrounds of each juror, who is peculiarly only referred to by number and not by name. Furthermore, we gain insights into the techniques they employ and difficulties they face in multi-party negotiation while trying to justify their stand and convince the others to switch over to their position. The movie incorporates light-hearted moments and comical dialogues to make it enjoyable for the viewers, and the technique of incrementally adding on to the narrative as the discussion progresses keeps the audience engaged. However, beneath the entertainment value of the film lie lessons in negotiation that we can learn from. It is an enriching movie that allows us to study the characteristics of negotiations and negotiators. It also shows us the relevance of the information in Roger Fisher's "Getting to Yes" book and the usefulness of principled negotiation, which we can apply in our daily lives.

Despite being a black and white film, 12 Angry Men was thoroughly enjoyable and left me with a changed perspective of old classic films. This film provided me with an insight on inherent human flaws such as biasness and our tendency to rely on emotions when handling issues. The different scenarios portrayed by the different jurors provided an accurate depiction of instances when we rely on emotions rather than facts when handling negotiations.
Sometimes black & white movies blow up your minds . This is one of greatest film that has ever been created .

Set in 1957, the monochrome film 12 Angry Men surprisingly did not seem any less relevant even when viewed more than 60 years later, highlighting disagreement, management and negotiation as timeless issues. The film showed Juror 8 as the only juror in a murder trial who did not vote for a guilty charge for the accused at the first vote. Over the course of the film, Juror 8 slowly but successfully manages to convince the other jurors that the case is not as clear as it seemed in court1. Tone
Throughout the discussion, viewers will notice that more often than not, the jurors who were persuasive raised their points without raising their voices. Yet, even while they were not particularly loud and aggressive, it did not undermine their effectiveness. 2. Be hard on the problem but soft on the people
We observe that Juror 8 to be hard on the problem to ensure a fair decision was made, yet he maintained softness and empathy in approaching the jurors - showing respect and acknowledging their right to their own opinions. While the negotiation took place in the context of the controlled setting of a movie, negotiations take place in our lives every day. Some negotiations may not result in an outcome that we came in to a discussion hoping to achieve. However, 12 Angry Men provide good tips on how we can conduct a negotiation.

12 Angry Men succinctly illustrates the importance of carefully analyzing arguments to identify the emotions and positions that conceal personal agendas propagated by people. The film highlights how various parties, like #3 and #10, were focused on superficial claims to base their decision of "guilty", while others were bigoted and unwilling to consider the perspectives of the other jurors. However, #8 exemplified the abilities of a skilled negotiator, convincing the entire jury to change their minds to a "not guilty" verdict, which would save a man's life. Even though merely working with reasonable doubt of the man's guilt, this was independent of whether he was truly guilty or not. The final decision was arrived through a systematic and thorough cross-examination of the facts on hand.

Going in thinking 12 Angry Men was a lame black and white film I had to watch for an assignment, I didn't think I was going to enjoy it as much as I did. Even though the film was set in one location, there was never a dull point and the conversations and debates between the jurors were always so intense and exciting. The film uses the decision-making process of 12 jurors to bring us on a roller-coaster of emotions. In the short one hour and 36 minutes, many uncomfortable issues were brought to light. This included discrimination, racism, and even more personal problems like self-purpose and worth. All these issues were presented to the audience in a very bite-sized way, with each juror embodying one, allowing us to see the parallels in our own lives. What I found most interesting was how the importance of being a good negotiator shined through for me in the film. 12 Angry Men was able to portray the wide spectrum of negotiators, from skilled and objective negotiators, to hot-headed and ego-centric ones. Through them, we were able to see the repercussions of allowing our emotions and personal pre-conceived notions overwhelm our decisions. I learnt to not be so quick to judge and to always consider the possibility of alternatives before being certain about something. There will always be things that we will not see or know. But yes, all in all, I truly enjoyed the movie as it left me thinking about the uncomfortable issues that we may not always want to deal with. I totally recommend watching this, even if you are someone who is not into older films. It's definitely worth your time!

Review title: A real classic film, but falls short of meeting realistic expectations
Review_body: The film '12 Angry Men' is set in a courtroom where a jury of twelve men deliberate the charge of a defendant of a murder trial with the aim of reaching a unanimous vote. Operating on the principle of reasonable doubt, the film appeals to viewers as it depicts the contrasting ways of examining a situation that is both intriguing and captivating, even better that it was in black and white. Although the film as a whole had many captivating moments, it was a line expressed by juror 9 that changed the game for me. He voted for 'not guilty' and explicitly explained his vote, "I respect his motives, but the boy in trial is probably guilty; but I want to hear more." This line impressed upon me two things: that a person who was previously on the far opposite end of a view could be so open-minded as to consider the possibility of a contrasting view even with little concrete evidence, and that the negotiator (juror 8) could succeed at persuasion just by communicating his motives, which is more significant in the face of such a weak case. This showed me how effective and powerful persuasion can be, especially since beliefs shape our actions which in turn affects everything and everyone.In spite of this, there are also certain aspects of the film that are merely fictional and problems that are harder to deal with in reality. This is seen in one part of the film where the protagonist gave up his interests at one point in time and arrange for a secret ballot where he would change his vote to 'guilty' if there was a unanimous vote. Although juror 9 did vote 'not guilty' and the group of men began negotiating again, realistically it would not happen as parties would move on and forget about your interests once you give them up. The storyline falls short in this aspect but the film was still enjoyable as a whole.

The film 12 Angry Men by Sidney Lumet gives us a picture of a very probably real life situation of negotiations taking place. It follows 12 white male jurors trying to reach a verdict in the murder trial of a Puerto Rican teenager who is accused of knifing his father. The task the jurors have is grave as their decision must be unanimous in whether this boy is to be given the death penalty. Despite the gravity of the situation, not everyone perceives it this way. I enjoyed how the complexity of human prejudice is explored in the film. While its central story is based on the fact that 12 white jurors are reaching a verdict on a migrant Puerto Rican teenager's murder trial, the film also turns the prejudice on the viewer - in our assumption that all 12 men are the same. It is highly enjoyable and spurs good thought.

12 angry men was a captivating and exciting film from start to end. The film depicts the story of a jury's decision on the case of a teenage boy charged with the murder of his own father based on reasonable doubt. Twelve jurors, each with different backgrounds, personalities and interests are involved. The theme of prejudice is explored in this film. Through the use of a single setting, Lumet effectively delves into the personalities of each juror and their motivations that pushed them to make their decision on the case. Juror 10 is a racist bigot, who makes no effort to hide his contempt for residents of the slums. Juror 10 frequently has emotional outbursts, and offended Juror 5, who grew up in a slum, and disrespected the elderly Juror 9 with his crude remarks. Juror 3 is a forceful man who is intolerant of others, with a strong but hidden prejudice against juveniles, which reminds him of his estranged son. Driven by their prejudice, Jurors 3 and 10 were unable to distinguish their emotions from their perception of the problem, causing their decisions to lose objectivity. The film reveals to me how prejudice can significantly distort and influence people's ability to rational decisions.
The truth of whether the boy actually committed the murder was never revealed, even at the end of the film. The truth matters little when compared to the significance of how what we perceive may not actually be what is, which the film was able to put across splendidly. My main takeaway is that when entering a new discussion, it is important to be receptive and empathetic but yet firm toward positional pressure in order to produce a convincing argument. This is a film that is worth watching.

12 Angry Men is indeed a classical film depicting how sensible negotiations can lead to a optimal outcome and drastically change the views of a human of ripe years.12 men decided the fate of a young murder suspect accused of killing his father. Everyone showed the ugly side of their temperament, flaring up at different trigger points. However, good negotiation techniques, and not compromise, allowed Juror 8 and his supporters to navigate the tough debate and come to a fair decision. This movie shows how we can apply negotiation skills to our daily social situations to help all of us reach outcomes that are mutually beneficial to the parties involved.

In this movie 12 Angry Men, 12 jurors convene in a jury room to decide the verdict of an 18-year-old boy from the slums who had been convicted of murdering his father. Since the premise of the movie revolves around the negotiation of whether the boy is guilty or not guilty, three key insights are highlighted with regards to successful, principled negotiation: firstly, reconciling interests rather than positions; secondly, the strategy of negotiation jujitsu to counter positional bargaining; and lastly, the importance of separating people from positions and remembering that negotiation is between human beings. This is an insightful movie which allows us as humans to think and ponder about our words and actions in a disagreement, using them to intentionally turn it into a successful negotiation instead.

The film itself is as steady as a rock: the performances given by each of the jurors are absolutely outstanding. And the camerawork is amazing. But the thing that's really astonishing, is how well the script is written. 
At the beginning of the movie it seems a clear cut case: The boy's guilty, no doubt.
But as it progresses, and each time juror number eight, or nine, notices something new, something that make's you thing about the boys guilt, or innocence, the case get's, like Lee Cobb said: Twisted and turned. Not in a way that the boy is clearly guilty and should get the death penalty. But in a way that it's very unlikely the boy hasn't done it, but as heroic as juror number eight is in his way, he stands up to the fate of the boy, because there's room for reasonable doubt. And can get everyone to agree with the fact that it is not for a hundred percent sure the boy has done it.
Although juror number eight knows that the chance the boys guilty, is maybe even greater than the chance he's not, he still believes in that room for reasonable doubt. And in second chances.

Review title: You'll never forget the first time you see it.
Review_body: 12 Angry Men is such a simple concept, masterfully executed by Director Sidney Lumet.12 Jurors must vote unanimously to decide whether or not a young man is guilty of murdering his father. The film is set into motion when all but 1 of the 12 jurors vote guilty.Juror No.8 (Henry Fonda) makes the case that the young man on trial could be guilty however he wants to consider the case a little more before deciding to vote and ultimately deciding the fate of the accused. As tensions start to run high Juror No. 8 faces an uphill battle to convince the other 11 jurors there may perhaps be more than meets the eye.When I was watching it for the first time I felt like I was Juror No.13, constantly on the edge of my seat awaiting the next big revelation.On a promotional piece for the film it says "IT EXPLODES LIKE 12 STICKS OF DYNAMITE!". I couldn't agree more. 12 Angry Men is a riveting, powerful and uplifting experience that's message is still relevant today.Without a doubt it will always be one of my favorite movies of all time. What are you waiting for? Go watch it ;)

Review title: The very best acting I've ever seen
Review_body: It's hard to believe that twelve men locked in a room talking about a murder case could be any kind of a decent movie. But this is one of the best movies I've ever seen. Henry Fonda's performance in this movie is one of the greatest acting performances I've ever seen. Twelve men locking in a room discussing a case literally gave me chills and goosebumps throughout most of the movie. My heart stopped and my jaw dropped when Fonda took the knife out of his pocket and stabbed it into the table. This movie is not for everyone. I used to know a guy who said multiple times in the period that I knew him, "If nothin' blows up, it ain't a movie." Not everyone is as big of fan of movies as I am, but if you consider yourself a fan of all types of genres and superior acting, then find a way to watch this movie. There is a good reason this movie, (at the time of which I am writing this review,) is in the top five highest rated movies of all time on IMDb.

Honestly, this is one of those 'must see' movies that will never feel like a chore to watch. Sometimes we feel like we have to see a movie just because it's one of the greats; this one you'll want to watch because it IS great.The acting here is superb. Hardly surprising considering the cast, but it could have easily gone wrong. The characters here perfectly stride the line of archetypes without falling into the trap of caricature. In just 96 minutes, you get 12 characters who all feel real, and who all have their own desires, biases, and motivations. Most movies are impressive if they can flesh out one or two characters to the degree that all 12 jurors get in this movie.And speaking of the lean 96 minute running time mentioned in the last paragraph, 12 Angry Men keeps moving at a pace you wouldn't expect for a movie about 12 people who pretty much just talk in a single room for the entire movie (well, two rooms if you count a few minutes spent in the bathroom). Even those with a short attention span should be able to enjoy this one.I don't think I'm blowing anybody's mind by giving a great review to a movie that's been getting great reviews for half a century, but I just want to make sure that YOU see this movie. Don't put it in your Netflix queue and forget about it. Don't talk about renting it one day. Get it now, watch it tonight, and never regret it.

'12 Angry Men' does not use names and could be set anywhere. Each character represents the different characters in society and its deeply-rooted flaws. Hence, it paints a bigger picture of constitutional inequality and susceptibility to manipulation within the American judicial system that all countries can relate to, including Singapore. Hence, this movie serves as a poignant warning that everyone has a social responsibility to respect the judicial system as a platform to protect individual rights, regardless of background.

***Spoiler Alert***This film provides an incredible platform in understanding negotiations. While it might be slow at the beginning, it captures the audience's attention with its nuances and necessitates focus in order to follow the storyline.This film captures perfectly what a jury might look like in America, and allows the viewer to deliberate on the process together with the jury, helping to develop civic-mindedness whilst understanding the implications of the legal system as a layman. For example, the film requires viewers to understand the term "beyond reasonable doubt" as one of the core tenets of the negotiation.Overall, I would highly recommend this movie.

Review title: A surprisingly entertaining and interesting movie
Review_body: When I was assigned to watch 12 Angry men for one of my classes, I was dreading it a bit as I thought that the movie would be very long and boring. This is especially so after I heard that the movie was in black and white. However, the movie surprised me greatly by being surprisingly entertaining and interesting. It would not be a stretch to say that the movie captivated me for almost a 100 minutes.The flow of the movie was also very logical and easy to follow. The movie opens with a introduction of each of the juror's character traits which helped to contextualise the rest of the movie. It is interesting how the character traits of the jurors were illuminated as the movie went on.I was really impressed with how Juror 8 used negotiation techniques such as separating people from the problem and focusing on the interest of the various parties to eventually obtain a fairer judgement for the defendant. By maintaining an objective criteria, Juror 8 managed to tease out the subtle inaccuracies in the testimonies of the witnesses. I enjoyed seeing how the movie unfolded and to see how the inaccuracies in the testimonies were debated on.Personally, my favourite part of the movie was when Juror 2 who was portrayed as meek in the beginning of the movie, stepped up to assert that there might be some discrepancies with how the switchblade was used. This not only helped as a plot device to propel the story forward, it also showed how the negotiation process managed to help a person grow little.

Review title: A very insightful movie with learning points in negotiation
Review_body: Watching the movie, in conjunction with reading the book "Getting to Yes" by Roger Fisher, I was pleasantly surprised at how the theories from the book came to "live" in the movie. The movie truly showed very strong elements of principled negotiation of the protagonist contrasted against the positional bargaining of the other jurors. The reasons behind the different negotiating style was also well explained and in line with what the book posited, such as positional bargaining, which is a result of not being able to separate people from the problem and neglecting one's interests to focus on the positions instead. Furthermore, interesting negotiation techniques were used by the protagonist to be able to share his opinions effectively and deal with stubborn jurors, which could be an inspiration to how we handle negotiations and conflicts in our lives

Review title: A brilliant film about negotiation and the workings of law
Review_body: "12 Angry Men" is a 1957 American courtroom drama film adapted from a teleplay of the same name by Reginald Rose. The film describes the story of a 12-men jury in a New York City courthouse deliberating the case of an 18-year-old Hispanic slum-born boy who had allegedly stabbed his father to death. The objective criterion used was reasonable doubt - that is, if the jury had any reasonable doubt as to the culpability of the boy, they were to return a verdict of not guilty. Conversely, if the jury had no reasonable doubt as to how culpable the boy was, they were to return a verdict of guilty, and the boy would be sentenced to death accordingly."12 Angry Men" compellingly explores many powerful techniques of negotiation - that is, how to build consensus amongst a group of people with starkly different personalities and worldviews. "12 Angry Men" is an outstanding masterpiece of a film that has withstood the test of time. The film relies less on elaborate special effects and costumes but impresses all the same simply because of the excellent plot and consummate acting."12 Angry Men" is a film highly recommended to people young and old. Because it is a courtroom drama, "12 Angry Men" may be especially interesting to law students, lawyers and those interested in the workings of law.
Well acted, well written and beautifully directed. This is a must for any cinephile.

I have watched it over 50 times overe the years, and always find somethig new - in the words, the camera, the characters, the mood...
(I have read the one, two, and three star reviews - who complain it is in black & white, or set in just one room, or only had men!! They do not see the irony, that THEY are the jurors with irrational presuppositions that we are all wary of. THEY are the jurors in that room that decide the fate of a person. Read their reviews - and be very afraid. (Note: you can hate the film, but your reasons must be rational)).

Enjoy.

Review title: A true Classic........Enjoy every moment of this brilliant masterpiece.
Review_body: 12 Angry Men" is a fascinating but uncomfortably close examination of the workings of constitutional law and the fact that a person's life can be in the hands of 12 people who are themselves full of faults, failings and doubts. The film makes it graphically clear that the people who enforce law are all too human and that there are calm, decent people like Juror #8 (Fonda) who are willing to weigh the evidence and look for innocence rather than rush toward the verdict of guilt..........This is undoubtedly one of the top 3 movies i have seen and i give it a Ten on Ten......... A true Classic........Enjoy every moment of this brilliant masterpiece.

Review title: The simplicity makes this movie incredible
Review_body:
I was looking at the Top Rated Movies at IMDB and I felt me interested to watch "12 Angry Men" after I read its synopsis, so even though I don't have so much time I decided to watch it, considering that is a short movie.
It was one of my best choices, because I've never seen a movie which basically revolves arround a single scenario holding someone so much time. The concept is very simple and the dialogues are as simple as such, but the movie's magic is at the storie's unfolding, showing how a single person can influences other people only using arguments.
Finally, for me, it's a fantastic movie and it's obligated for some professionals (e.g. lawyers).

I was very positively blown away by this movie. I definitely must say that it is one of the best I hae seen. Something that I find very fascinating about it is that it keeps you interested in the story and on the edge of your seat even though it takes place in the same room for the entirety of it and it is just made up of conversation. in that respect it reminds me of "Rope" by Alfred Hitchcock, which I think is a masterpiece.
The performances are very engaging and I think that all of the characters were portrayd in a very well done and believeable way. Henry Fonda is obviously very good but I was happy that he didn´t steal the show despite being the main character. All of the characters had their time to shine and their own little character arc.
Before watching this I wouldnt have thought that a bunch of people arguing could be this entertaining to watch however later on I was legitemately sad to see it end. I belive I could honestly watch this movie for days. It just never gets dull.
The mystery aspect of the movie I think was very well handled for the most part. The fact that we do not know any of the evidence before the debate of the twelve jurors was very good because that way there were a lot of awesome scenes where a crucial piece of evidence was presented that turned the argument around. (A good example for this is the scene where Henry Fonda pulls out the knife.)
In the end the audience never finds out whether the young man actually comittted the murder or not which seems somwhat dissappointing to me but when thinking about it further I guess that´s the point of the movie. Its not really about whether the boy is guilty or not. It´s just about what you choose to believe.Overall this movie made for a very entertaining watch and I would recommend this movie to everybody. See it as soon as possible. I really loved it a lot and if it was possibl to give half stars I would give it an 8.5 instead of an 8 to get a more accurate rating. Maybe on a second viewing I´ll give it a 9 but that remains to be seen.Excellent film.
